awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of a fluorescence-activated cell analyzer (FACS) to enhance undergraduate classroom and research experiences
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Randolph-Macon College to acquire a flow cytometer, an instrument capable of measuring up to 16 molecular properties of thousands of individual cells per second.  Access to the flow cytometer will facilitate undergraduate research and training across disciplines and institutions. In particular, research projects supported by the instrument will enable the mentorship and training of over 25 undergraduate research students per year at Randolph-Macon College and Longwood University.  An additional 50 students per year will benefit from the inclusion of the instrument in laboratory courses at Randolph-Macon College.   Further, the acquisition of the cytometer will enhance outreach activities to Latina high school women enrolled in Randolph-Macon College's NSF-funded Pathways to Science Program and local middle school students.  Overall, the addition of the flow cytometer to Randolph-Macon College will enhance the scientific training and literacy of undergraduate students, Latina high school students, local middle school students, and the general public.

The flow cytometer will support research projects directed by seven faculty from two departments and three institutions, spanning a broad range of investigative topics.  These topics include: a range of immunology studies, neural physiology, mammalian fertility, the evolution of brewer's yeast, and other topics.   Overall these projects will enhance our understanding of the natural world and are likely to generate a significant degree of collaboration between the investigators and senior personnel, enhancing the already strong intellectual community at Randolph-Macon College and Longwood University. Results from projects enabled by the acquisition of the flow cytometer will be communicated in peer-reviewed publications and at regional and national scientific conferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to enhance the scientific infrastructure of Randolph-Macon College by purchasing purchase a flow cytometer and an automated sampling robot, thereby also facilitating research projects, contributing to the development of future scientists, and promoting public engagement with science and technology. Flow cytometry enables researchers to characterize the size and protein expression profiles of millions of cells within a tissue or sample.  With knowledge of these characteristics, one can identify and quantify subpopulations within a larger population of cells.  Now installed in Copley Science Center, the NovoCyte 3005 flow cytometer and NovoSampler Pro autosampler has supported the research projects of five R-MC faculty in Biology and Chemistry.  These faculty have mentored 24 undergraduate science-majors in independent research projects utilizing the flow cytometer to examine the impact of malnutrition on immune system function, mammalian fertility, the evolution of domesticated yeast, the efficacy of a novel metallodrug as a cancer treatment, and the genomic content of a newly discovered water mold. Over a dozen undergraduate students presented their research involving the flow cytometer at the national level. The instrument was also utilized in course-based research projects within four courses in which 25 Biology majors and 7 non-science majors participated.  Lastly the instrument was featured in demonstrations and workshops with 30 Latina high school students as a part of the Pathways to Science Program at RMC.  Overall, the addition of the flow cytometer and autosampler has enhanced research productivity and contributed to the training and professional development of over 50 undergraduate and high school students.  It is likely that experience with our high quality, powerful scientific instrument has fueled student interest in science and technology while also enhancing their competitiveness for graduate programs and jobs in science.
